Name: hong hua
carthamus tinctorius
zang hong hua
Biological: Crocus sativus L. (zang hong hua; fan hong hua)
Common: English: safflower, African saffron, American saffron, bastard saffron, dyer's saffron, false saffron
Français: carthame de teinturiers, safran bâtard

Geography: Carthamus tinctorius L. (hong hua): Henan; Hebei; Zhejiang; Sichuan; Yunnan.

Crocus sativus L. (zang hong hua; fan hong hua): Europe; Middle East; India (Kashmir); imported through Xizang (Tibet); now also cultivated in China. Those called Zang hong hua (Tibetan hong hua) are not grown in Xizang (Tibet), but are grown in the Middle East and imported through Tibet (Xizang).
Properties: Carthamus tinctorius L.: acrid, warm (辛, 溫).
Crocus sativus L. (zang hong hua; fan hong hua): slightly cold, sweet (性微寒, 味甘).
Meridians: Crocus sativus L. (zang hong hua; fan hong hua): Heart; Liver.
Maladies Treated: Lumps in intestines and bowels (癥瘕結塊). Part used: flower (Flos Carthami).
Sores and carbuncles; swollen boils (瘡癰腫痛). Part used: flower (Flos Carthami).
Pain from impact injuries; injuries from impact; physical injuries with blood stasis and pain (跌仆傷痛). Part used: flower (Flos Carthami).
Rheumatoid arthritis; wind-damp impediment pain (風濕痺痛). Part used: flower (Flos Carthami).
Irregular menses (月經不調). Part used: flower (Flos Carthami).
Amenorrhea with abdominal pain; pain in stopping of menses (經閉腹痛). Part used: flower (Flos Carthami).
Postpartum blood stasis abdominal pain (產後瘀痛; 產後瘀阻腹痛). Part used: flower (Flos Carthami).
Measles that have erupted and then retract; heat constraint with blood stasis where rash color is not lively red (麻疹出而復收，或熱鬱血滯，斑疹色不活紅). Part used: flower (Flos Carthami).
Angina of coronary diseases (冠心病心絞痛). Part used: flower (Flos Carthami).
Thromboangiitis obliterans (血栓閉塞性脈管炎/脫疽). Part used: flower (Flos Carthami).
Enlargement of the liver and spleen (肝臟與脾臟腫大). Part used: flower (Flos Carthami).
Fractures (骨折). Part used: flower (Flos Carthami).
Dislocated joints (脫臼). Part used: flower (Flos Carthami).
Sprains (扭傷). Part used: flower (Flos Carthami).
Painful joints; purpura; eczema: treated with formula Dang Gui Hong Hua Yin (當歸紅花飲). Part used in formula: flower (Flos Carthami).

Crocus sativus L. (zang hong hua; fan hong hua) specific: warm diseases with heat entering the blood aspect causing rashes; heat constraint with blood stasis with rash color not red (溫熱病，熱入血分發斑，熱鬱血淤，斑色不紅). Part used: stigma (by context of Crocus sativus; usage stated as similar to hong hua).
Medical Function: Invigorates circulation and breaks up blood stasis. Small amount invigorates the blood; large amount dispels blood clots.
Promotes menstruation (emmenagogue).
Key herb for blood stasis therapy; often paired with tao ren (peach kernel).
For invigorating circulation, commonly used with dang gui (Chinese angelica root), chuan xiong (Ligusticum chuanxiong rhizome), and shao yao (peony root).
For dispelling blood stasis, commonly used with san leng (Sparganium rhizome), e zhu (zedoary rhizome), and da huang (rhubarb root).
Crocus sativus L. (zang hong hua; fan hong hua): stronger than hong hua; additionally cools the blood and resolves toxins (涼血解毒)

Cardiovascular system: Small doses can mildly stimulate the heart, lower the resistance of coronary arteries, increase their flow and the nutritive blood flow to the heart muscle; large doses have an inhibitory effect.

Effect on platelets: Inhibits platelet aggregation and thus inhibits thrombosis formation.

Effect on the uterus: In the pregnant uterus, small doses can significantly increase tonic or rhythmic contractions; large doses can cause uterine constriction and even spasm.

Protection in ischemic/hypoxic brain conditions: Studies show it can increase the threshold of rat in oxygen deprivation; experimental evidence shows increased tolerance to hypoxia in mice (animal experiments).

Lowers blood lipids.

Anti-bacterial and anti-fungal effects.

Analgesic effect.

Diuretic effect.

Immune function enhancement.

Anti-inflammatory effect.

Anti-spasmodic effect.

Emmenagogue (induces menstrual flow).

Diaphoretic (induces perspiration).

Induces interferon.
Dosage:
Carthamus tinctorius L. (hong hua): 0.5 g to 2 g (0.5～2克).
Crocus sativus L. (zang hong hua; fan hong hua): 1 to 1.5 g in decoction.
Samples of Formulae:
Painful or blocked menses: Tao Hong Si Wu Tang — Composition: Tao Ren (peach kernel) 10 g, Hong Hua (safflower flower) 6 g, Dan Shen (Salvia miltiorrhiza root) 12 g, Dang Gui (Angelica sinensis root) 12 g, Chi Shao (red peony root) 12 g, Chuan Xiong (Ligusticum chuanxiong rhizome) 7 g. Alternatively, use Ge Xia Zhu Yu Tang.

Painful abdomen due to blood stasis after birth: Hong Hua San; Tuo Hua Jian.

Painful joints, purpura, eczema: Dang Gui Hong Hua Yin — includes Dang Gui (Angelica sinensis root) and Hong Hua (safflower flower).

Measles with blood stasis, rash color not lively red: use Hong Hua (safflower flower), Dang Gui (Angelica sinensis root), Zi Cao (purple gromwell root), Da Qing Ye (Isatis leaf).

Coronary disease angina: use Hong Hua (safflower flower), Dan Shen (Salvia miltiorrhiza root), Chuan Xiong (Ligusticum chuanxiong rhizome), Chi Shao (red peony root).

Thromboangiitis obliterans: use Hong Hua (safflower flower), Dang Gui (Angelica sinensis root), Tao Ren (peach kernel), Chi Shao (red peony root), Ru Xiang (frankincense resin).

Postpartum abdominal pain due to blood stasis: Hong Hua San (source: Formulae of Gynecology by monks of Xiao Shan Bamboo Temple of Zhejiang province, Qing Dynasty) — Ingredients: Hong Hua (safflower flower) 38 g (一兩), Niu Xi (Achyranthes root) 38 g (一兩), Su Mu (Sappan wood) 30 g (八錢). Preparation: add white wine and simmer to a serving size (生白酒煎八分); drink while warm.

Editor's note regarding Hong Hua San: the dosage of Hong Hua (safflower flower) at one liang (about 38 g) seems too high. Adjust according to the patient’s syndrome.
Contraindications: Do not use in cases of bleeding, heavy menses, or ulcer. Contraindicated in pregnancy. Do not use concurrently with blood-thinning drugs such as warfarin (苄丙酮香豆素鈉(華法林)) or heperin to avoid causing bleeding. 出血，潰瘍病人，月經過多者，與孕婦忌用。
Notes:
Herb categorization nuance: described as a Liver-channel blood-aspect herb (肝經血分藥).

Zang hong hua (Crocus sativus L.; fan hong hua): usage is similar to hong hua but stronger; additionally cools the blood and resolves toxins; more often used in warm diseases with heat entering the blood, with rashes where the color is not vivid red. Contraindications for zang hong hua are the same: bleeding, heavy menses, and pregnancy are contraindications.

Adulterants and impurities of hong hua: Adulteration often adds impurities to increase weight, or uses other flowers dyed and mixed in.
- Impurities: clean hong hua mixed with fine sand, talc powder, corn syrup, red and apricot-yellow colorants.
- Counterfeits: old chrysanthemum flowers and Coptis (huang lian) rootlets pulverized, dyed, and processed to resemble hong hua.

Identification methods:
1) Weight-based: pure hong hua (standard burlap bag) weighs 20–23 kg per bag. Counterfeits often have plastic film inside the bag, are loosely packed, and can exceed 25 kg.
2) Color-based: pure hong hua has bright color; counterfeit hong hua looks dull.
3) Hand-feel: pure hong hua feels soft and puffy; counterfeit feels somewhat hard and resistant; gentle rubbing leaves fine debris in the hand.
4) Water test: place the material in a cup, add hot water, stir gently, and let stand. Pour off the upper half; if debris remains at the bottom, it is counterfeit or contains impurities. If dyed chrysanthemum was used, the surface color washes off, revealing the original material.

Medical Function: Tonic for stomach.
Rid of wind.
Promote sweating.
Promote urination.
Promote Lung qi.
Strengthen muscles and bones.
Promote circulation.
Antipyretic effect of cinnamaldehyde: promotes sweating, dilates blood vessels of the skin, and promotes secretion of sweat glands when the decoction is taken warm.
Antispasmodic and analgesic; inhibits the central nervous system.
Gastroprotective: inhibits restraint water-immersion–induced gastric ulcers in laboratory rats; promotes bile secretion.
Antibiotic effect: inhibits pathogenic filamentous fungi.

Diuretic effect: promotes urination when the decoction is taken cooled.
Dosage:
Gui zhi: 3–10 g per day for boiling.
Rou gui: 1–5 g used as powder form, or added to the decoction when it is ready for use.

Contraindications:
Contraindicated in liver yang ascending, warm‑febrile diseases, yin deficiency with heat, and heat in the blood with vomiting.
Use caution during pregnancy or in cases of excessive menstrual bleeding.
Overdosage may be toxic to the kidney and may cause bleeding in the urinary tract.
Do not overcook: effectiveness may lessen because the effective volatile oil evaporates.
Cinnamaldehyde (cinnamic aldehyde), a main ingredient of cassia oil, is the toxic component.
Notes:
Gui zhi is from the young branches of cinnamon trees.
Rou gui is the thick bark of the trees.
Usually rou gui is used in tonic applications while gui zhi is used for expelling wind and dampness, but they can be used interchangeably.
